sub_topic: Identifying the Eulerian and Hamiltonian paths in a graph.
message_1:
Consider the following undirected graph with 6 vertices and 9 edges: 

![Graph Image](https://i.imgur.com/LjA888c.png)

Is there a Hamiltonian path or circuit that exists in this graph? If so, provide the sequence of vertices in the path/circuit. If not, explain why.
message_2:
Yes, there is a Hamiltonian circuit in this graph. A Hamiltonian circuit is a closed loop on a graph where every vertex is visited exactly once, and the starting and ending vertices are the same.

Here is the sequence of vertices in the Hamiltonian circuit:

1 → 2 → 3 → 6 → 4 → 5 → 1

This circuit visits every vertex exactly once and returns to the starting vertex, satisfying the conditions for a Hamiltonian circuit.
